This line has been interpreted in various ways by fans and critics, but here's one possible explanation:

Patrick Bateman is an embodiment of 1980s yuppie culture, where superficiality and appearances reign supreme.
This request is not meant to be taken literally; rather, it's a darkly comedic and satirical commentary on the excesses of 1980s yuppie culture.
On one level, Patrick is expressing his extreme boredom, disillusionment, and disconnection from the shallow conversation at the dinner party.

On one level, the line suggests that Patrick has become so bored and disillusioned with his wealthy, superficial lifestyle that he craves something new and exciting – even if that means indulging in an outrageous or taboo experience, like eating a stray cat.
However, the line also has deeper symbolic meaning.
Cats often represent independence and self-reliance, which Patrick, as a wealthy and entitled executive, sorely lacks.
Throughout the book and film, Patrick is portrayed as a shallow, narcissistic character who objectifies women and treats them as disposable objects.
Throughout the book and film, Patrick is portrayed as a consumerist caricature, someone who reduces everything and everyone around him to mere commodities.
In this sense, asking for a stray cat to eat represents the ultimate form of conspicuous consumption: devouring something wild, unpredictable, and disposable.
By asking for a stray cat to eat, Patrick is highlighting his own emotional emptiness and disconnection from reality.
He objectifies women, people, and objects, perceiving them only through the lens of their material value and social status.
By asking for a stray cat to eat, he's highlighting the absurdity and emptiness of his materialistic worldview.
His statement about wanting to eat a stray cat serves as a grotesque manifestation of this consumptive mindset, highlighting the vacuity and cruelty at its core.
His desire for a "stray cat" represents a kind of primal craving for authenticity and raw experience, unmediated by the artificial trappings of wealth and status.
By requesting a stray cat to eat, he's extending this reductionism to its absurd extreme: treating living creatures as disposable food items.
His request for a stray cat to eat serves as a grotesque parody of the way he objectifies and consumes people, relationships, and experiences.

By requesting to be fed a stray cat, he's illustrating the ultimate expression of this worldview: consuming something completely random, useless, and perhaps even repulsive, simply for the sake of novelty.
He objectifies people, treating them as objects for his own gratification, whether that's through material possessions, sex, or violence.
By requesting a stray cat as food, he's taking this attitude to its absurd extreme.
His demand for a stray cat as food serves as a metaphor for the excesses of capitalist consumption, highlighting how people (and animals) are reduced to mere objects for exploitation.

By demanding to be fed a stray cat, Patrick is effectively saying, "Give me something raw, unrefined, and untamed" – essentially, something authentic, which is an ironic request given his artificial and self-obsessed persona.
By asking for a stray cat, he's taking his objectification of living beings to a twisted extreme.
By asking for a stray cat to eat, he's highlighting the absurdity of his own materialistic desires.
By asking for a stray cat to eat, Patrick is essentially highlighting the absurdity of his own overindulgent nature and the lengths to which people will go to satisfy their desires.

By asking for a stray cat to eat, Patrick is highlighting the hypocrisy of his social circle, which claims to value refinement, taste, and sophistication but secretly desires base, primal experiences.
By asking for a stray cat to be fed to him, he's effectively highlighting his own empty materialism and the dehumanizing effects it has had on him.
By saying "feed me a stray cat," he may be highlighting the emptiness and artificiality of his own existence.
By saying "feed me a stray cat," he's essentially asking for a new, exotic, and perhaps forbidden consumable to satisfy his jaded palate.
By asking for a stray cat, Patrick is implying that he wants to consume something raw, unrefined, and genuine – as opposed to the artificial, polished life he leads.

The request for a stray cat is a metaphorical extension of this: he wants to consume something utterly disposable, insignificant, and potentially repulsive, mirroring the way he treats other human beings as disposable objects.
His inner world is empty and devoid of genuine human connection.
By requesting a stray cat for dinner, he's implying that he views people (and animals) as nothing more than objects to be consumed and discarded at his whim.

By asking for a stray cat to eat, he is essentially requesting to devour something base and primal, which would allow him to momentarily escape his suffocating world of designer suits and champagne parties.
By requesting a stray cat as food, he's essentially treating another living being as just another disposable product to satisfy his jaded desires.
His obsession with material possessions, social status, and physical appearance reflects his own inner emptiness.
His request for a stray cat is a gross parody of the upper-class fondness for exotic cuisine, highlighting the absurdity of those who seek out bizarre or status-driven dining experiences.
He objectifies people, objects, and experiences, treating them as disposable items for his own gratification.
By asking to be fed a stray cat, Patrick may be expressing his desire to consume something that is wild, unpredictable, and outside the bounds of conventional societal norms.
By requesting a stray cat as food, Patrick is, in effect, making a dark joke about the depths of his own emptiness and ennui.
He's saying, essentially, that he's so desperate for stimulation that he'll consume anything – including the lowest, most marginalized creatures.
It's a sign of his spiritual bankruptcy, highlighting how his life has become devoid of genuine connections, empathy, or compassion.
The stray cat represents something wild, untamed, and genuinely meaningful – qualities that are antithetical to Patrick's suffocating, artificial world.
It's a manifestation of his existential despair, as well as his utter disdain for societal norms and expectations.
It's a twisted manifestation of his frustration with the artificiality and monotony of his high-society existence.
He's implying that even the most absurd, inhumane, and unpalatable thing (i.e., a stray cat) would be preferable to the stifling tedium of his own luxurious life.
The stray cat represents something outside the confines of his gilded cage, something authentic and raw – which, of course, he'd ultimately destroy and consume, reflecting his sociopathic tendencies.
